intro: Conradina grandiflora var. grandiflora, commonly known as the Florida flame flower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Solanaceae family, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in well-drained soils in open woods and sandhill habitats. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a slight pubescence. The flowers, which range in color from orange to red, bloom in the summer and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
